verses.text: The wicked flee when no one pursues, but the righteous are bold like a lion.
verses.comment: Boldness and confidence are marks of a righteous life. Spiritual strength comes from inner purity and trust in God's protection, foreshadowing those who are steadfast in faith through all trials. Compare the lion imagery to Christ as the Lion of Judah (Rev. 5:5).

verses.text: When a land transgresses, many are its rulers, but with a man of understanding and knowledge, stability endures.
verses.comment: Good leadership, grounded in wisdom, preserves order. Throughout biblical history, God often raises up wise leaders for the sake of stability and peace. There is an implication here for God’s chosen shepherds guiding His people.

verses.text: A poor man who oppresses the needy is like a driving rain that leaves no food.
verses.comment: Oppression from those who should understand suffering is especially damaging. The image is of rain destroying the harvest, a reversal of rain's natural good, echoing warnings against injustice found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Those who forsake the law praise the wicked, but those who keep the law strive against them.
verses.comment: Obedience to God’s law makes one an enemy to evil, illustrating the central role sacred tradition and law play in the spiritual combat against wickedness.

verses.text: Evil men do not understand justice, but those who seek the LORD understand it completely.
verses.comment: True understanding comes from seeking God, supporting the concept of ongoing spiritual formation and the transformative power of divine grace.

verses.text: Better is a poor man who walks in integrity than one who is crooked in his ways, though he is rich.
verses.comment: Material wealth is secondary to upright living. The preference for poverty with integrity reflects Christ’s teaching on treasures in heaven (Matt. 6:19-21).

verses.text: Whoever keeps the law is a discerning son, but a companion of gluttons shames his father.
verses.comment: Adherence to God’s law is a mark of spiritual maturity and familial honor, a theme resonating throughout Scripture and church tradition.

verses.text: Whoever multiplies wealth by interest and profit gathers it for one who is generous to the poor.
verses.comment: Earthly riches, even if accumulated unjustly, will ultimately be transferred to those who use them mercifully. The sovereign providence of God governs the redistribution of temporal wealth.

verses.text: If anyone turns his ear away from hearing the law, even his prayer is detestable.
verses.comment: Prayer must be united with obedience; neglect of divine law makes worship vain. This connection between law, prayer, and worship is shown in both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: Whoever leads the upright into evil will fall into his own pit, but the blameless will inherit good.
verses.comment: Divine justice ensures that evil schemes return on their originator, while the innocent are rewarded, foreshadowing the beatitudes (Matt. 5:3-12).

verses.text: A rich man is wise in his own eyes, but a poor man who has understanding will see through him.
verses.comment: Worldly wisdom without humility is deceptive. Spiritual insight is not bound to wealth and often exposes pride, just as Christ elevated the humble (Luke 1:52).

verses.text: When the righteous triumph, there is great glory, but when the wicked rise, people hide themselves.
verses.comment: The influence of true righteousness brings blessing to a community, showing the importance of godly leadership, echoed in the life of the apostles.

verses.text: Whoever conceals his sins will not prosper, but he who confesses and forsakes them will obtain mercy.
verses.comment: Confession and repentance bring about divine mercy; hidden sin is a barrier to spiritual growth. This anticipates the Christian practice of sacramental confession, though emphasizing heartfelt repentance.

verses.text: Blessed is the one who always fears, but whoever hardens his heart will fall into calamity.
verses.comment: A healthy reverence and humility protect from disaster, echoing the call to keep one's heart soft before God, underscoring the role of ongoing spiritual conversion.

verses.text: Like a roaring lion or a charging bear is a wicked ruler over poor people.
verses.comment: Tyrannical leadership brings fear and suffering, a pattern seen throughout Israel’s history and in warnings to shepherds of God’s people.

verses.text: A ruler who lacks understanding is a great oppressor, but he who hates unjust gain will prolong his days.
verses.comment: Leaders must rule with wisdom and justice. The promise of long life for rejecting greed hints at God’s reward for virtue.

verses.text: If a man is burdened with blood guilt, he will be a fugitive until death; let no one help him.
verses.comment: The seriousness of shed blood echoes God’s judgment. Unrepented mortal sins bear consequences, echoing the ancient principle of justice and atonement.

verses.text: Whoever walks in integrity will be saved, but whoever is crooked in his ways will suddenly fall.
verses.comment: Living righteously leads to salvation, a spiritual and literal promise. The path to holiness is narrow but secure, reminiscent of Jesus’ sermon about the narrow gate.

verses.text: Whoever works his land will have plenty of bread, but whoever follows empty pursuits will have plenty of poverty.
verses.comment: Diligence in one’s vocation brings reward, while laziness leads to ruin. Fidelity to daily duty is an important principle for spiritual as well as material well-being.

verses.text: A faithful man will abound with blessings, but whoever hastens to be rich will not go unpunished.
verses.comment: Faithfulness draws God’s favor; greed brings trouble. Trust in God’s providence over earthly gain is a consistent biblical theme and points to seeking spiritual riches.

verses.text: To show partiality is not good; for a person can do wrong even for a piece of bread.
verses.comment: Justice must be impartial, regardless of bribes or influence. Human weakness can corrupt judgment even for trivial gain, reminding us to examine our consciences regularly.

verses.text: A stingy man is eager to get rich, and does not know that poverty will come upon him.
verses.comment: The pursuit of wealth for its own sake leads, paradoxically, to loss. Generosity and detachment from riches are traits praised by Christ.

verses.text: Whoever rebukes a man will afterward find more favor than he who flatters with his tongue.
verses.comment: Correction, though difficult, leads to eventual respect. Scripture encourages admonition as a work of mercy for the good of souls.

verses.text: Whoever robs his father or mother and says, 'There is no wrong,' is a companion to a destroyer.
verses.comment: Disrespect to parents is equated with great moral evil. The family is sacred, and honoring one’s parents is foundational to the life of grace.

verses.text: A greedy man stirs up strife, but the one who trusts in the LORD will prosper.
verses.comment: Greed causes division; trust in God brings peace and fruitfulness. This calls the believer to reject selfish ambition for the sake of unity.

verses.text: Whoever trusts in his own mind is a fool, but he who walks in wisdom will be delivered.
verses.comment: Human wisdom is insufficient apart from divine guidance; humble reliance on revealed truth is the way of salvation. The verse points to the necessity of spiritual direction.

verses.text: Whoever gives to the poor will not lack, but he who hides his eyes will have many curses.
verses.comment: Generosity is blessed and withholding compassion brings misfortune. Caring for the poor is central in Christian ethics and a mark of sanctity.

verses.text: When the wicked rise, people hide themselves, but when they perish, the righteous increase.
verses.comment: Social and spiritual renewal follow the removal of wickedness. The increase of righteousness refers, both literally and spiritually, to times of revival often led by holy men and women.
